title-group.article-title: Advocating for Access to Evidence for Evidence-Based Practice in School Health

contrib.aff: Director of Nurses, Waltham Public Schools, Waltham, MA
School Nurse, Warren Prescott School, Boston, MA

bio.p: Marie has been a school nurse for 19 years. She is the director of nurses in Waltham, Massachusetts, and is the current NASN director from Massachusetts.

Mary Jane has been a school nurse in Boston, Massachusetts, for 22 years. She has recently completed her PhD and her research interest is the associations of school nurse activities and student outcomes.

ref.citation: BultasM. W. McLaughlinL. (2012). Using evidence-based practice in the school health room. NASN School Nurse, 1(28), 35–40. doi:10.1177/1942602X12465964

FacchianoL. Hoffman SnyderC. (2012). Evidence-based practice for the busy nurse practitioner: Part two: Searching for the best evidence to clinical inquiries. Journal of the American Academy of Nurse Practitioners, 24, 640–648.
GibbsL. E. (2003). Evidence-based practice for the helping professions: A practical guide with integrated multimedia. Pacific Grove, CA: Brooks/Cole-Thompson Learning.
HaighC. A. (2011). Wikipedia as an evidence source for nursing and healthcare students. Nurse Education Today, 31, 135–139. doi:10.1016/j.nedt.2010.05.004
Institute of Medicine. (2010). The future of nursing: Leading change, advancing health. New York: National Academy of Science.
O’BrienM. J. DeSistoM. C. (2013). Every study begins with a query: How to present a clear research question. NASN School Nurse, 28(2), 83–85. doi:10.1177/1942602X 12475094
